review.title: State-Space Inference for Non-Linear Latent Force Models with Application to Satellite Orbit Prediction
review.abstract: Latent force models (LFMs) are flexible models that combine mechanistic modelling principles (i.e., physical models) with non-parametric data-driven components. Several key applications of LFMs need non-linearities, which results in analytically intractable inference. In this work we show how non-linear LFMs can be represented as non-linear white noise driven state-space models and present an efficient non-linear Kalman filtering and smoothing based method for approximate state and parameter inference. We illustrate the performance of the proposed methodology via two simulated examples, and apply it to a real-world problem of long-term prediction of GPS satellite orbits.

metadata.title: State-Space Inference for Non-Linear Latent Force Models with Application to Satellite Orbit Prediction

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Gaussian processes (GPs) are stochastic processes, which are commonly used to represent uncertainties of dynamic systems in many applications as tracking, navigation and automatic control systems (Jazwinski, 1970; Bar-Shalom et al., 2001; Grewal & Andrews, 2001; Maybeck, 1982).In these applications, Gaussian processes are typically white, and the processes are used as stochastic inputs into physical models such as driving forces of mechanical systems, which are described in terms of ordinary differential equations (ODEs).Appearing in Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Machine Learning, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK, 2012. Copyright 2012 by the author (s) / owner (s).In a machine learning context, Gaussian processes (Rasmussen & Williams, 2006) are used as non-parametric models for unknown functions.

sections.heading: 2. Latent Force Models
sections.text: Latent Force Models (LFMs) (A ́ lvarez et al., 2009) are a relatively new modelling approach in which mechanistic modelling principles (i.e. physical models) are combined with non-parametric data-driven components. They have been used successfully, e.g. for approximate prediction of transcription factors (Honkela et al.). For example, Lawrence et al. (2006) modelled the time-dependent expression levels {xj (t)} Nj = 1 of N genes with a first-order system ODEsdxj (t) dt = Bj + R ∑ r = 1 Sj, rgj (ur (t) − Djxj (t), j = 1,. N (1), in which the drive processes {ur (t)}} Rr = 1 (representing the transcription factors, TFs) were determined independently.

sections.heading: 5. Simulated Experiments
sections.text: This section demonstrates the performance of the proposed framework using two simulated examples.

sections.heading: 5.1. Estimation of Transcription Factors
sections.text: First, we look at the TF model (1) with three different nonlinear functions: (i) g (u (t))) = e (t) γ + eu (t) (sat-uration), (ii) g (u (t)) = 1 γ + eu (t) (repression) and (iii) g (u (t)) g (t))) (exponential). In this case, the drift model is linear and thus can approximately be solved as a function of u (t) (Lawrence et al., 2006), and therefore it is possible to implement Laplace and MCMC for it.

sections.heading: 5.2. Tracking a Ballistic Target on Reentry
sections.text: Next, we look at the tracking of a ballistic target that re-enters the atmosphere with a sensor that measures the deviation from the target = 9.0 = · · · · · In this example, the drift and measurement models are not linear, so Laplace and MCMC are not applicable to the state inference. For the sake of simplicity, we are only looking at a one-dimensional case (i.e., the target falls directly to the ground), but the approach works similarly in a general 3D setting. The movement of the target is assumed to follow the equation (Li & Jilkov, 2001) [dr dv] = [− v a (r, v, t) + g (t) + u (t)]] dt + [qr 0 − qv], where r − dβv] is the height and v the speed of the target. We assume that the acceleration is caused by the towing force a (r, v, t).

sections.heading: 6. GPS Satellite Orbit Prediction
sections.text: As a case study, we consider the problem of predicting the orbit of a GPS satellite and the acceleration of solar radiation. Accurate modeling of the forces acting on a GPS satellite is required in a number of applications and real-time applications that require predicting the orbit (Seppa nen et al., 2012). The motion equation for the satellite can be written as a (vector) Markov model whose acceleration is caused by unknown forces acting on the satellite. Here, r and v represent the 3D position and velocity vectors of the satellite in an inertial coordinate system fixed to an arbitrary frame of reference. The deterministic acceleration of the motion model isa (r, t) + asrp, where the acceleration is fixed on a satellite.

sections.heading: 6.1. Modeling the Unknown Forces
sections.text: As a first step in modeling, we would like to get an insight into what the unknown forces look like. To do this, we assume separate GP smoothing priors for each component of u (r, v, t). Instead of placing the GP priors directly on the inertial coordinate system used in the integration, we place them on the radial, tangential and normal components of an RTN coordinate system with unit vector (r, v) uR (t) uN (t), where R (r, v) is a matrix, the RTN coordinates are transformed into the inertial coordinate system used in the integration. Thus, the model for the unknown forces isu (r, v, t) uR (t) uT (t), where R (r, v) is a matrix, the RTN coordinates are transformed into the inertial coordinate system used in the integration 9, and each of the latent forces isu (r, v, t) 9, 8, uR (t) uR (t) uT (t) uN (t), where R (t) is a matrix, the RTN (r, v) 9, the RTN coordinates are transformed into the inertial coordinate system 9, the RTN coordinates are transformed into the inertial coordinate system 9, 8, and each of inertial coordinate system 9, 8, 8, 8, and each of the unknown forces isu (r, v, t) uR (t) uR (t) uR (t) uT (t) uT (t) uT (t) uN (t) uN (t) is a matrix (t) uN (t) uN (t), t), where R (t) is a matrix is a matrix, where R (r (r, v) 9, v), 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, uT, uT, uT, uT, uR (t, t, t, t, t) uT (t) uT (t) uT, t) uT (t

sections.heading: 6.2. Quasi-Periodic Model for Latent Forces
sections.text: In order to model the quasi-periodicities of the latent forces, we use a stochastic resonator model previously used to model periodic phenomena in the brain (Sa � rkka � et al., 2012). We model the periodic component as an overlay of resonators of Form2cn (t) dt2 = − (2πnf) 2cn (t) + wn (t), (13) where the additive white noise components (t) have a spectral density qn. As Sa � rkka � et al. (2012) has shown, this model can be written in the state spatial formdx (t) = Fx (t) dt + L dβ (t) u (t) = Hx (t) + b + (t), (14) which is compatible with the frame presented in this article. In Equation (14) we also have a thrust term (which could also be time variable) to a noise layer used as a prelayer and a resonator to zero.

sections.heading: 6.3. Example Online Prediction Results
sections.text: We are now applying the constructed quasi-periodic latent force model to predict the satellite orbit, and comparing the results with those achieved only with the deterministic model. We are considering an online prediction scenario in which we observe the position and velocity of the satellite at certain time intervals, and between these intervals the models are used to provide predictions. We are using 30 days of position data (collected every 15 minutes) of satellite 31 since early January 2010. The regions of the observed data are shown in shades of gray in Figure 3. In the quasi-periodic latent force model we are using 7 harmonic components for the model uR (t), uT (t) and 10 in uN (t). As a period, we have used a little less than one day that we have observed to be a clear period in the estimated latent forces. The rest of the model parameters have been optimized with respect to the marginal probability in which the smoothed mean model of integration of kuttas is given by a short-term segment of the GP model.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we have shown how nonlinear latent force models can be represented as nonlinear noise-driven state-of-the-art models, resulting in the application of efficient filtering and smoothing algorithms for state and parameter conclusions. The potential weakness of the approach is the underlying Gaussian approach to the state posterior, but as we have shown, there are many applications where the approach works well. The advantage of the approach is that it is computationally light compared, for example, with pure particle filtering and MCMC-based approaches, whose calculation requirements may be unfeasible for practical application.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors would like to thank Arno Solin, Janne Ojanen and anonymous reviewers for their feedback, which has significantly improved the work. They acknowledge the financial support provided by the Finnish Doctoral Program in Computer Science, the Finnish Foundation for Technology Promotion, the Emil Aaltonen Foundation and the Tampere Doctoral Program in Information Science and Engineering.

Using this view on GP priors, the conversion of linear latent force models into linear-Gaussian statespace models was recently considered by Hartikainen & Särkkä (2011). In this paper, we consider conversion of non-linear latent force models into non-linear statespace models.
In general, this is a difficult task that has been well studied in the field of stochastics and filtering theory (Jazwinski, 1970).
The formal Bayesian continuousdiscrete filter consists of separate prediction and update steps (Jazwinski, 1970), which are recursively iterated forward in time.

The expectations in the equations above are taken over the approximating Gaussian distribution, and can be numerically computed with sigma-point and cubature integration methods (see, Särkkä, 2007; Singer, 2008; Särkkä, 2010; Arasaratnam et al., 2010; Särkkä & Sarmavuori, 2012). As was discussed by Singer (2011), the Gaussian filter also computes approximations to the conditional measurement likelihoods p(yk|y1:k−1) ≈ N(yk|μk,Sk), which can be used in marginal likelihood based parameter learning via the factorization p(y1:T |θ) = ∏T k=1 p(yk|y1:k−1, θ), where θ denotes a vector of unknown parameters.
An alternative way of performing state inference would be to use a particle filter (Doucet et al., 2001), which approximates the posterior with sequential importance sampling.
We could then use particle MCMC methods (Andrieu et al., 2010) for estimating the unknown parameters.

The difficulty in using particle filters with SDEs is that when the state transition density cannot be evaluated in closed form, one is restricted to usage of the dynamic model as the importance distribution (Andrieu et al., 2010), which leads to inefficient sampling.
The drift model in this case is linear and can thereby be solved approximately as a function of u(t) (Lawrence et al., 2006), and thus it is possible to implement Laplace and MCMC for it.

metadata.abstractText: Latent force models (LFMs) are flexible models that combine mechanistic modelling principles (i.e., physical models) with nonparametric data-driven components. Several key applications of LFMs need nonlinearities, which results in analytically intractable inference. In this work we show how non-linear LFMs can be represented as nonlinear white noise driven state-space models and present an efficient non-linear Kalman filtering and smoothing based method for approximate state and parameter inference. We illustrate the performance of the proposed methodology via two simulated examples, and apply it to a real-world problem of long-term prediction of GPS satellite orbits.
